case_name: Appellant Company v. Pritam Singh Gill

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 1171 of 1970 filed by special leave.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 1171 of 1970. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and order dated February 18, 1970 of the Labour Court, Delhi in L.C.A. No. 709 of 1968.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated February 18, 1970 of the Labour Court, Delhi in L.C.A. No. 709 of 1968. P. Malhotra, N. S. Das Bahl, P. S. Mahindru and Sat Pal, for the appellant. D. A dlakha, Promod Swarup and S. S. Khanduja, for respondent No. 1. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by Dua, J. Facts necessary for understanding the short but im- portant point arising for decision in this appeal by special leave are these

facts.text: Appellant is a company incorporated under the Companies Act, 1956 with registered office in New Delhi.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant is a companypany incorporated under the Companies Act, 1956 with its registered office in New Delhi. Its entire share capital has been subscribed by the Central Government. Pritam Singh Gill, respondent number 1, in this appeal was employed by the 1208Sup CI/72 appellant as Junior Engineer at its Bhopal office with effect from the 9th November, 1962 at Rs. 280/- p.m. as basic salary with other allowances.

facts.text: Entire share capital of appellant subscribed by Central Government.

anchor.surface_text: Its entire share capital has been subscribed by the Central Government. Pritam Singh Gill, respondent number 1, in this appeal was employed by the 1208Sup CI/72 appellant as Junior Engineer at its Bhopal office with effect from the 9th November, 1962 at Rs. 280/- p.m. as basic salary with other allowances. On October 5, 1964 he was suspended and this order, of suspension remained in force till September 18, 1967.

facts.text: Pritam Singh Gill employed by appellant as Junior Engineer at Bhopal office from 9th November 1962 at Rs. 280 p.m. basic salary with allowances.

anchor.surface_text: Pritam Singh Gill, respondent number 1, in this appeal was employed by the 1208Sup CI/72 appellant as Junior Engineer at its Bhopal office with effect from the 9th November, 1962 at Rs. 280/- p.m. as basic salary with other allowances. On October 5, 1964 he was suspended and this order, of suspension remained in force till September 18, 1967. He was dismissed from service on September 19, 1967.

facts.text: Pritam Singh Gill suspended on October 5, 1964, suspension in force till September 18, 1967.

anchor.surface_text: On October 5, 1964 he was suspended and this order, of suspension remained in force till September 18, 1967. He was dismissed from service on September 19, 1967. During the period of suspension, on October 7, 1965, the respondent was trans- ferred to Delhi. On June 15, 1968 the respondent applied to the Labour Court at Delhi under s. 33C 2  of the Industrial Disputes Act, 1947  hereinafter called the Act  for companyputing the benefits and amount he was entitled to receive alleging that the appellant had number paid to him such amounts and benefits.

facts.text: Pritam Singh Gill dismissed from service on September 19, 1967.

anchor.surface_text: He was dismissed from service on September 19, 1967. During the period of suspension, on October 7, 1965, the respondent was trans- ferred to Delhi. On June 15, 1968 the respondent applied to the Labour Court at Delhi under s. 33C 2  of the Industrial Disputes Act, 1947  hereinafter called the Act  for companyputing the benefits and amount he was entitled to receive alleging that the appellant had number paid to him such amounts and benefits. The appellant companytested the respondents claim on various grounds.

facts.text: During suspension, Pritam Singh Gill transferred to Delhi on October 7, 1965.

The appellant companytested the respondents claim on various grounds. The, Labour Court framed the following four issues

facts.text: Pritam Singh Gill applied to Labour Court Delhi on June 15, 1968 under s.33C(2) for computing benefits and amount alleging non-payment by appellant.

anchor.surface_text: On June 15, 1968 the respondent applied to the Labour Court at Delhi under s. 33C 2  of the Industrial Disputes Act, 1947  hereinafter called the Act  for companyputing the benefits and amount he was entitled to receive alleging that the appellant had number paid to him such amounts and benefits. The appellant companytested the respondents claim on various grounds. The, Labour Court framed the following four issues Whether the application is number legally maintainable ? Whether this companyrt has numberjurisdiction to entertain this petition ?

facts.text: Appellant contested respondent's claim on various grounds.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant companytested the respondents claim on various grounds. The, Labour Court framed the following four issues Whether the petitioner has been dismissed with effect from 19-9-1967, if so its effect ? Whether the applicant is entitled to. any of the benefits claimed ? and decided all of them in favour of the respondent who was held entitled to Rs. 5,195/- as balance of salary at the rate of Rs. 1501p.m. for the period of suspension and also other allowances, the total amount companyputed being Rs. 10,259.98.

The, Labour Court framed the following four issues Whether the application is number legally maintainable ? Whether this companyrt has numberjurisdiction to entertain this petition ? Whether the petitioner has been dismissed with effect from 19-9-1967, if so its effect ? Whether the applicant is entitled to. any of the benefits claimed ? and decided all of them in favour of the respondent

facts.text: Labour Court decided all issues in favour of respondent, held entitled to Rs. 5,195 as balance salary at Rs.150 p.m. for suspension period plus allowances, total Rs.10,259.98.

anchor.surface_text: and decided all of them in favour of the respondent who was held entitled to Rs. 5,195/- as balance of salary at the rate of Rs. 1501p.m. for the period of suspension and also other allowances, the total amount companyputed being Rs. 10,259.98. Before us the appellant only questioned the jurisdiction of the Labour Court to entertain the respondents application under s. 33C 2  of the Act because, according to the submission, the respondent, having already been dismissed, had ceased to be a workman on the date of the application.

facts.text: Appellant questioned only jurisdiction of Labour Court before Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: Before us the appellant only questioned the jurisdiction of the Labour Court to entertain the respondents application under s. 33C 2  of the Act because, according to the submission, the respondent, having already been dismissed, had ceased to be a workman on the date of the application. After his dismissal, argued Shri Malhotra learned companynsel for the appellant, the respondent ceased to be a workman and had, therefore, numberlocus standi to approach the Labour Court under s. 33C 2  and the Labour Court had numberjurisdiction to entertain the respondents application.

facts.text: Appellant conceded that suspended workman can invoke s.33C(2).

anchor.surface_text: It may be stated that the appellant did number companytend that a workman under suspension is disentitled to seek relief under s. 33C 2  and indeed, it was specifically companyceded that a suspended workman companyld invoke this section for relief because by suspension he does number cease to be a workman as defined in the Act.

the total amount companyputed being Rs. 10,259.98. Before us the appellant only questioned the jurisdiction of the Labour Court to entertain the respondents application under s. 33C 2  of the Act because, according to the submission, the respondent, having already been dismissed, had ceased to be a workman on the date of the application.
As a result of the foregoing discussion, this appeal fails and is dismissed with companyts.

anchor.surface_text: Section 2 s  defines workman to mean ,,any person  including in apprentice  employed in any industry to do any skilled or unskilled manual, supervisory, technical or clerical work for hire or reward, whether the terms of employment be express or implied, and for the purposes of any proceeding under this Act in relation to an industrial dispute, include- any such person who has been dismissed, discharged or retrenched in companynection with, or as a companysequence of, that dispute, or whose dismissal, discharge or retrenchment has led to that dispute, but does number include any such person- who is subject to the Army Act, 1950, or the Air Force Act, 1950 or the Navy  Discipline  Act, 1934 or who is employed in the police, service or as an officer or other employee of a prison or who is employed mainly in a managerial or ad- ministrative capacity or who, being employed in a supervisory capacity, draws wages exceeding five hundred rupees per mensem or exercises, either by the nature of the duties attached to the office or by reason of the powers vested in him, functions mainly of a managerial nature.

issues.text: whether s. 33C 2 can be invoked by a dismissed workman in respect of benefits and salary due, to him for the period prior to the date of his dismissal.

anchor.surface_text: The sole question we are thus called upon to decide is, whether s. 33C 2  can be invoked by a dismissed workman in respect of benefits and salary due, to him for the period prior to the date of his dismissal. It may be stated that the appellant did number contend that a workman under suspension is disentitled to seek relief under s. 33C 2  and indeed, it was specifically conceded that a suspended workman could invoke this section for relief because by suspension he does number cease to be a workman as defined in the Act.

holdings.text: Section 33C(2) of the Industrial Disputes Act can be invoked by a dismissed workman in respect of benefits and salary due to him for the period prior to the date of his dismissal.

anchor.surface_text: The sole question we are thus called upon to decide is, whether s. 33C 2  can be invoked by a dismissed workman in respect of benefits and salary due, to him for the period prior to the date of his dismissal. It may be stated that the appellant did number companytend that a workman under suspension is disentitled to seek relief under s. 33C 2  and indeed, it was specifically companyceded that a suspended workman companyld invoke this section for relief because by suspension he does number cease to be a workman as defined in the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Purposive construction of s.33C(2) as speedy execution-like remedy for existing rights; repugnancy in applying strict s.2(s) definition would defeat legislative intent by allowing employers to dismiss to evade claims.

holdings.text: The term 'workman' in s.33C(2) includes a person who was employed during the period of the claim even if no longer employed at time of application, due to repugnancy in subject or context with s.2(s).

anchor.surface_text: Now, it is noteworthy that s. 2 of the Act, which is the definition section begins... with the clause, unless there is anything repugnant in the subject or context.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.2 definitions subject to repugnancy clause; strict application to s.33C(2) repugnant as it undermines speedy individual remedy purpose, harmonizes with legislative history and analogous execution proceedings.

holdings.text: Labour Court under s.33C(2) has jurisdiction to determine existence of workman's right to benefit before computing monetary value.

anchor.surface_text: In Chief Mining Engineer... the legislative history indicates that the legislature... recognised the need of individual workmen of a speedy remedy to enforce their existing individual rights and therefore inserted s. 33A in 1950 and s. 33C

holdings.reasoning_summary: Following Chief Mining Engineer and analogous to executing court powers; incidental to computation duty, mere denial by employer does not oust jurisdiction.

holdings.text: The application under s.33C(2) is legally maintainable despite dismissal.

anchor.surface_text: The, Labour Court framed the following four issues Whether the application is number legally maintainable ? Whether this companyrt has numberjurisdiction to entertain this petition ? ... and decided all of them in favour of the respondent

holdings.reasoning_summary: Affirmation of Labour Court findings by dismissing appeal; claim relates to existing pre-dismissal rights enforceable individually without s.10 reference.

holdings.text: Decisions of Madras High Court and others upholding s.33C(2) claims by ex-workmen for prior benefits are approved.

anchor.surface_text: Shri Malhotra, learned counsel for the appellant, contended that all these decisions require reconsideration because they ignore a vital point in construing s. 2 s  which defines workman.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Consistent with repugnancy clause and purposive approach; rejects call for reconsideration.

holdings.text: Central Bank of India v. S. Rajagopalan distinguished; does not bar pre-dismissal claims under s.33C(2).

anchor.surface_text: In support of this submission he relied on the Central Bank of India v. S. Rajagopalan 1 . At p. 156 of the report it was observed there that If an employee is dismissed or demoted and it is his case that the dismissal

holdings.reasoning_summary: Claim here not challenging dismissal or seeking post-dismissal relief, but only pre-dismissal suspension benefits.

holdings.text: No opinion expressed on interpretation of Minimum Wages Act s.20.

anchor.surface_text: We are aware of a conflict of decisions in some High Courts, on the interpretation of s. 20 read with s. 2 i  of the Minimum Wage,-, Act, .12 of 1948. This aspect was number canvassed before us and, therefore, we should number be deemed to express any opinion on the companyrectness or otherwise of either view.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Issue not argued; decision confined to Industrial Disputes Act.

precedents.citation: Central Bank of India v. S. Rajagopalan 1

anchor.surface_text: Central Bank of India v. S. Rajagopalan 1

precedents.case_name: Central Bank of India v S Rajagopalan
precedents.cited_proposition: A dismissed or demoted employee cannot claim recovery of salary under s. 33C(2) if challenging the dismissal as wrongful; must raise industrial dispute
precedents.cited_holding: If an employee is dismissed or demoted and it is his case that the dismissal or demotion is wrongful, it would not be open to him to make a claim for the recovery of his salary or wages under s. 33C(2)

precedents.citation: Messrs Kesoram Cotton Mills Ltd. v. Gangadhar ors. 2

anchor.surface_text: Messrs Kesoram Cotton Mills Ltd. v. Gangadhar ors. 2

precedents.case_name: Kesoram Cotton Mills Ltd v Gangadhar
precedents.cited_proposition: Suspended workman not entitled to wages for suspension period if misconduct proved and dismissed
precedents.cited_holding: Ordinarily, the law is that a workman may be suspended pending enquiry and disciplinary action. If after the enquiry the misconduct is proved the workman is dismissed and is not entitled to any wages for the suspension period

precedents.citation: Chief Mining Engineer, East India Coal Co. Ltd. v. Rameswar ors. 1

anchor.surface_text: Chief Mining Engineer, East India Coal Co. Ltd. v. Rameswar ors. 1

precedents.case_name: Chief Mining Engineer East India Coal Co Ltd v Rameswar
precedents.cited_proposition: Scope of s. 33C(2): Labour Court can determine disputed right to benefit before computing it; wider than s. 33C(1); for individual rights

precedents.citation: U.P. Electric Supply Co. v. R. K. Shukla 1

anchor.surface_text: U.P. Electric Supply Co. v. R. K. Shukla 1

precedents.case_name: UP Electric Supply Co v RK Shukla
precedents.cited_proposition: Labour Court has jurisdiction to entertain claim in respect of existing right arising from employer-employee relationship

precedents.citation: R. B. Bansilal Abhirchand Mills Co. P Ltd. v. The Labour Court, Nagpur 2

anchor.surface_text: R. B. Bansilal Abhirchand Mills Co. P Ltd. v. The Labour Court, Nagpur 2

precedents.case_name: RB Bansilal Abhirchand Mills Co Pvt Ltd v Labour Court Nagpur
precedents.cited_proposition: Labour Court jurisdiction under s. 33C(2) not ousted by denial of claim; must determine if entitled to computation

precedents.citation: Tiruchi-Srirangam Transport Co., P Ltd. v. Labour Court, Madurai 1

anchor.surface_text: Tiruchi-Srirangam Transport Co., P Ltd. v. Labour Court, Madurai 1

precedents.case_name: Tiruchi-Srirangam Transport Co Pvt Ltd v Labour Court Madurai
precedents.cited_proposition: Dismissed/retrenched workman can invoke s. 33C(2) for benefits due for prior period; 'any workman' includes ex-workmen for existing rights

precedents.citation: Manicka Mudaliar M v. Labour Court, Madras 1

anchor.surface_text: Manicka Mudaliar M v. Labour Court, Madras 1

precedents.case_name: Manicka Mudaliar v Labour Court Madras
precedents.cited_proposition: Ex-employee can file under s. 33C(2) for arrears of salary and notice pay

anchor.surface_text: Bachittar Singh v. Central Labour Court, Jullundur 3

anchor.surface_text: The sole question we are thus called upon to decide is, whether s. 33C 2  can be invoked by a dismissed workman in respect of benefits and salary due, to him for the period prior to the date of his dismissal. It may be stated that the appellant did number companytend that a workman under suspension is disentitled to seek relief under s. 33C 2  and indeed, it was specifically companyceded that a suspended workman companyld invoke this section for relief because by suspension he does number cease to be a workman as defined in the Act.
As a result of the foregoing discussion, this appeal fails and is dismissed with companyts.
